value.description: A comma-separated list of all slugs associated with the taxonomy.

contentId.description: Generally this will be the client ID from the underlying API data.

contentType.description: The content type of the post, with variations for particular custom screens.

subscriptionExperience.description: The type of subscription required to access the content, if any.

categories.description: A comma-separated list of all category slugs.

channel.description: The slug of the root ancestor of the primary category.

primaryCategory.description: The slug of the primary category.

publishDate.description: The date that the content was published.

authors.description: A comma-separated list of all author display names.

tags.description: A comma-separated list of all tags associated with the content.

taxonomies.description: Key-value pairs for any custom taxonomies asociated with a particular content type.

info.title: Mobile BFF
info.description: The Mobile BFF is the primary backend API for our native mobile applications.

get.description:
## Filtering

Each response includes a `facets` array that contains a `filterKey`
and an array of `terms`, each containing a `query`.

To filter the search results we combine filter keys with queries in the
following format:

```
filter[<filterKey>]=<query>
```

For example, this is how we might filter the results to return only recipes:

```
filter[type]=match:recipe
```

Or, for recipes with a minimum user rating of 5:

```
filter[type]=match:recipe&filter[minUserRating]=gte:5
```

### Logical operators

Queries across multiple filter keys are considered AND queries, meaning
the results returned must match the queries defined for all filters.
Within the queries for each filter key we have a little more flexibility.

To perform an AND query for a particular filter key we join queries with a plus
symbol, for example:

```
filter[minUserRating]=gte:1+lt:3
```

To perform an OR query for a particular filter key we use the comma separator,
for example:

```
filter[type]=match:recipe,post
```

When building your filter object up from JavaScript code it might',
look something like this:

```
filter: {
  type: 'match:recipe,post',
  minUserRating: 'gte:1+lt:3',
}
```

Where the above example assumes you are using the Mobile BFF Client, or some
other library that handles formatting query parameters in the
array bracket style.

## Sorting

Any `filterKey` returned in the `facets` array can also be used for sorting.

Search results can be sorted in ascending or descending order using the
following format:

```
sort[<filterKey>]=<asc|desc>
```

It is possible to sort on multiple properties. For example, to sort by the
newest items with the highest rating:

```
sort[userRating]=desc&sort[published]=desc
```

## Tabs

The settings returned from this endpoint include a list of `tabs`, where each
tab is a configuration used to make search requests with a set of default filters.
For example, we might have a tab for recipes and a tab for editorial lists.

The `filterKeys` and `sortOptions` defined for each tab can be used to filter
and sort the data.

See the **/search** endpoint for details of how to use these tabs and filter keys.
